pullRequest.body:
Provide instances
  * `Nontrivial (TensorAlgebra R M)` when `M` is a module over
    a nontrivial semiring `R`
  * `NoZeroDivisors (FreeAlgebra R X)` when `R` is a commutative
    semiring with no zero-divisors and `X` any type
  * `IsDomain (FreeAlgebra R X)` when `R` is an integral domain
    and `X` is any type
  * `TwoUniqueProds (FreeMonoid X)` where `X` is any type
    (this provides `NoZeroDivisors (MonoidAlgebra R (FreeMonoid X))`
    when `R` is a semiring and `X` any type,
    via `TwoUniqueProds.toUniqueProds`
    and `MonoidAlgebra.instNoZeroDivisorsOfUniqueProds`)
  * `NoZeroDivisors (TensorAlgebra R M)` when `M` is a free module
    over a commutative semiring `R` with no zero-divisors
  * `IsDomain (TensorAlgebra R M)` when `M` is a free module over
    an integral domain `R`

In Algebra.Group.UniqueProds:
* Rename `UniqueProds.mulHom_image_of_injective` to
  `UniqueProds.of_injective_mulHom`.
* New lemmas `UniqueMul.of_mulHom_image`, `UniqueProds.of_mulHom`,
  `TwoUniqueProds.of_mulHom` show the relevant property holds in the
  domain of a multiplicative homomorphism if it holds in the codomain,
  under a certain hypothesis on the homomorphism.

nodes.body:
This is all very nice, thanks!

I wonder whether this result should be more "generic" in terms of `(Two)UniqueProds` for Lists, Multisets, Finsets, as [TwoUniqueProds.instTwoUniqueProdsProdInstMul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/UniqueProds.html#TwoUniqueProds.instTwoUniqueProdsProdInstMul) works for products.

In fact, using a Lex order on Lists and an arbitrary linear order on the underlying type `X` should give an argument very similar to the one for the MVPolynomials result.

> I wonder whether this result should be more "generic" in terms of `(Two)UniqueProds` for Lists, Multisets, Finsets, as [TwoUniqueProds.instTwoUniqueProdsProdInstMul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/UniqueProds.html#TwoUniqueProds.instTwoUniqueProdsProdInstMul) works for products.

This should indeed work for `TwoUniqueSums` and `Multiset`, but none of the other types have an `Add` or `Mul` with the right semantics, so I don't think this can work there.

> This should indeed work for `TwoUniqueSums` and `Multiset`, but none of the other types have an `Add` or `Mul` with the right semantics, so I don't think this can work there.

Ah, I see!  What about exploiting a little of [TwoUniqueSums.of_covariant_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/UniqueProds.html#TwoUniqueSums.of_covariant_left), since FreeMonoid is cancellative?
I tried that, but it needs a linear order. Indeed, there should be some common result that both the instance in this PR and the one you refer to can be constructed from.

I'll try this when I have some more time.  What I had in mind was to use a lex ordering on Lists and any linear order on the base type `X`, i.e. one that you obtain via a LinearExtension.

In the multiset case, I think that you are also extracting both the min and the max for a lex order on any linear extension.  Anyway, I may have some time to try this out tonight or tomorrow, but this is just a way of golfing further the PR: I am happy with the results, even if I think that the proofs can be streamlined.

This is what I had in mind, but it requires an extra import:
```lean
import Mathlib.Order.Extension.Linear

@[to_additive "Any `FreeAddMonoid` has the `TwoUniqueSums` property."]
instance FreeMonoid.instTwoUniqueProds {κ : Type*} : TwoUniqueProds (FreeMonoid κ) :=
  -- put an arbitrary linear order on `κ`
  let _ : LE κ := { le := (· = ·) }
  have : PartialOrder κ := {
    le_refl     := Eq.refl
    le_trans    := @Eq.trans _
    le_antisymm := fun _ _ a _ ↦ a }
  let _ : LinearOrder κ := inferInstanceAs (LinearOrder (LinearExtension κ))
  -- use the lexicographic order on `List κ` induced by the order on `κ`
  let LO : LinearOrder (FreeMonoid κ) := List.instLinearOrderList
  -- show that a `CovariantClass` holds for `List`
  have : CovariantClass (FreeMonoid κ) (FreeMonoid κ) HMul.hMul LO.lt :=
    ⟨fun a b c bc ↦ List.Lex.append_left _ bc ..⟩
  TwoUniqueProds.of_covariant_right
```

I'd argue that that approach is backwards; we shouldn't have to put a weird order on `FreeMonoid`, there should be a  lemma stated in terms of a suitable map `f : FreeMonoid _ -> Y`, where the order goes on `Y`.

> I'd argue that that approach is backwards; we shouldn't have to put a weird order on `FreeMonoid`, there should be a lemma stated in terms of a suitable map `f : FreeMonoid _ -> Y`, where the order goes on `Y`.

I always find that this issue with random orders appearing is probably due to my initial input to `UniqueProds`.  This comes from the fact that a standard way of *proving* that `UniqueProds` holds for `X`, is to put an order on `X` and extract mins or maxs from `Finset`s of `X`.

However, the statement of `UniqueProds` makes no reference to a background order.  All of this is to say that, when you are putting an arbitrary order on something, just to prove `UniqueProds` it is probably an indication that a previous lemma that I put in the library assumed an order, but it could have been generalised to something without an order!

Anyway, I think that this discussion highlights the need for an improvement of the basics of the `UniqueProds` file.  This improvement, however, is out of scope for this PR.

I am happy with the current PR!

There's a trivial refactor I can do:
```lean
@[to_additive]
theorem of_graded_mul {X G : Type*} [Mul X] [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] [LinearOrder G]
    [CovariantClass G G (· + ·) (· < ·)] [CovariantClass G G (Function.swap (· + ·)) (· < ·)]
    {f : X → G} (hf : ∀ x y : X, f (x * y) = f x + f y)
    (hinj : ∀ a b c d : X, a * b = c * d → f a = f c → a = c ∧ b = d) :
    TwoUniqueProds X where
  uniqueMul_of_one_lt_card {A} {B} h := by
    sorry
```
and
```lean
/-- Any `FreeMonoid` has the `TwoUniqueProds` property. -/
@[to_additive "Any `FreeAddMonoid` has the `TwoUniqueSums` property."]
instance FreeMonoid.instTwoUniqueProds {κ : Type*} : TwoUniqueProds (FreeMonoid κ) :=
  TwoUniqueProds.of_graded_mul List.length_append (fun _ _ _ _ => by exact List.append_inj)
```
It doesn't seem terribly useful. Maybe there's a way to do it that fits in with the API around `GradedMonoid`.

> There's a trivial refactor I can do [...] It doesn't seem terribly useful.

I think we can assume we "Ain't Gonna Need It". It's very easy to do if someone does need it in future.

> Maybe there's a way to do it that fits in with the API around `GradedMonoid`.

This wouldn't be as cool (if it works at all), because it would need hypotheses that everything is nonzero all over the place.

I can shorten the proof by another few lines, but only by changing `rw`'s to term-mode stuff and making it hard to follow. I think it's ready to be merged.

> There's a trivial refactor I can do:

That looks like a nice refactor to me.

> > There's a trivial refactor I can do:
> 
> That looks like a nice refactor to me.

79faa1b10c

I'm not sure "graded" is precisely the word I want here. It's suggestive, at least.

Reviewers, thank you very much for your work on this. It's been an education.

Do you have any further suggestions?

* Do you think "grade" is ok? Can you see a better phrasing?
* ~~More docstrings?~~ [edit: done]
No more improvements have come to mind. @eric-wieser, any suggestions? Do you think this should be merged, and do you think it's ready? Anything else I should do (like ask another person to review)?

@adomani Do you remember why you called this lemma `mulHom_image_of_injective` in [#6723](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6723/commits/bebb7d8cba23140f843a053da8cd419facb9e896#diff-ebdf20b185bac5adc5a22ffdf53e7dfa74bb23fb34dfa47a761bb9dfa66c9fc1R233-R234)? I can't see `image` in the statement (but the proof uses `mulHom_image_iff`) and I think `of_injective_mulHom` might be a better name.
```
theorem mulHom_image_of_injective (f : H →ₙ* G) (hf : Function.Injective f) (uG : UniqueProds G) :
    UniqueProds H 
```

I've completed [a refactor](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/richard-copley/IsDomainTensorAlgebra...jyxu/IsDomainTensorAlgebra?expand=1) that cuts 18 lines off the PR and proves the more general
```
@[to_additive] theorem of_mulHom (f : H →ₙ* G)
    (hf : ∀ ⦃a b c d : H⦄, a * b = c * d → f a = f c ∧ f b = f d → a = c ∧ b = d)
    (uG : TwoUniqueProds G) : TwoUniqueProds H where
```
Feel free to merge!
Merged. `of_mulHom` is great!

> @adomani Do you remember why you called this lemma `mulHom_image_of_injective` in [#6723](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6723/commits/bebb7d8cba23140f843a053da8cd419facb9e896#diff-ebdf20b185bac5adc5a22ffdf53e7dfa74bb23fb34dfa47a761bb9dfa66c9fc1R233-R234)? I can't see `image` in the statement (but the proof uses `mulHom_image_iff`) and I think `of_injective_mulHom` might be a better name.
> 
> ```
> theorem mulHom_image_of_injective (f : H →ₙ* G) (hf : Function.Injective f) (uG : UniqueProds G) :
>     UniqueProds H 
> ```

I think that your name is indeed better.  I suspect that the name that I gave referred to an older version of the lemma that *might* have contained an image...
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

LGTM! I'll maybe give @adomani time to come give this a final look before merging

(and of course, you should look at it when it's not super late in case you had any more ideas)

LGTM! I'll maybe give @adomani time to come give this a final look before merging

(and of course, you should look at it when it's not super late in case you had any more ideas)

Thanks! I wouldn't have thought of the condition `hf` without you extracting `of_graded_mul`; my `hf` is simply a weakened form of your `hinj` that assumes `f b = f d` in addition. What I observed is that in
```
theorem of_graded_mul {X G : Type*} [Mul X] [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] [LinearOrder G]
    [CovariantClass G G (· + ·) (· < ·)] [CovariantClass G G (Function.swap (· + ·)) (· < ·)]
    {f : X → G} (hf : ∀ x y : X, f (x * y) = f x + f y)
    (hinj : ∀ a b c d : X, a * b = c * d → f a = f c → a = c ∧ b = d) :
    TwoUniqueProds X where
```
(let's pretend everything is multiplicative) `hf` is saying that `f` is a MulHom, and the conditions on G guarantees that G has TwoUniqueProds by [TwoUniqueProds.of_covariant_right](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/UniqueProds.html#TwoUniqueProds.of_covariant_right). Once I realized these it's natural to come up with `of_mulHom`.
This PR looks good to me now, but I just noticed no one ever added any labels to it? I added two and I'll wait a day for comments before sending it to maintainers.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.TensorAlgebra.Domain import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.TensorAlgebra.Grading ```

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
Is there a missing intermediate result about `FreeAlgebra` here?

Maybe! Here I used the maximality of the lengths of `xmax ∈ x.support` and `ymax ∈ y.support` to show that `xmax * ymax ∈ (x * y).support`. I'm not sure how the proof would go for `MonoidAlgebra R G` without some such length/degree/grade/valuation on `G`.
My claim here is that you are effectively using the fact that the `FreeAlgebra` has no zero divisors.
(I assume you weren't referring only to the part you highlighted? That is just `(e x) * (e y) = 0 ↔ x * y = 0` for an `e: AlgEquiv`, by an easy combination of existing lemmas, done twice.)

> My claim here is that you are effectively using the fact that the `FreeAlgebra` has no zero divisors.

Sorry, my last message wasn't in reply to the above. Messages don't seem to be popping up in a timely manner.

But I think I coincidentally addressed your point? Those lines don't require `NoZeroDivisors`, if I'm not mistaken.
See the commit I just pushed to see what I meant :)
I updated the bulleted list in the commit comment.
... and the module docstring.
@adomani, I seem to recall you had a more general version of this for `MonoidAlgebra`?
I'm thinking of https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/16299/files
I think the missing piece (which I think is true) is `UniqueProds (FreeMonoid X)`, from which everything else follows.
Wow! Yes, that's true (same proof, take maximal-`length` words). I'll write it up.
Done. Very cool, thank you!

Now `_root_.instNoZeroDivisorsMonoidAlgebraFreeMonoid` is gone, maybe the instances have better homes? Then there is no need for the new file `TensorAlgebra.Domain`.

`FreeMonoid.instUniqueProds` : ~~FreeMonoid.Basic~~ Algebra.Group.UniqueProds
`FreeAlgebra.instNoZeroDivisors` : FreeAlgebra.Basic
`TensorAlgebra.instNoZeroDivisors`, `TensorAlgebra.instDomain` : TensorAlgebra.Basis _[sic]_
Those look reasonable to me.
(done)
Is the stronger `TwoUniqueProds` true?

I just got back to my computer and it looks like I missed on a lot of fun here!

Anyway, I think that `TwoUniqueProds` should also hold: wherever the proof uses `max`, you could have used `min` just as well and this should be enough for `TwoUniqueProds` to go through.
Choose two words of _minimal_ length ... let me check that.

Yes, that'll work. Search-and-replace 'max' for 'min' and fix up a few things for an alternate proof of `UniqueProds`. That leaves a little housekeeping for edge cases. I'll have to leave that for another day, as it's getting late.

> I'll have to leave that for another day

... or stay up late and do it badly ...
Needs golf.

> I just got back to my computer and it looks like I missed on a lot of fun here!

Yeah!
> Anyway, I think that `TwoUniqueProds` should also hold: wherever the proof uses `max`, you could have used `min` just as well and this should be enough for `TwoUniqueProds` to go through.

Believe it or not, I didn't see this message until just now.
Can you add this for `FreeAlgebra` too?
99eecd81c1

```suggestion
  uniqueMul_of_one_lt_card {A} {B} h := by
```
Since we renamed `mulHom_image_of_injective`, I've now also renamed `mulHom_image_iff` for consistency.
And added deprecated aliases. (I doubt anyone is using them, but still ...)
